channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iraqis Who Flee Fighting in Falluja Find Hardship and Hunger
item.description: Survivors reach aid camps hungry, thirsty and scared, and their ordeals are not over: They are in the arms of a government without the resources to care for them.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Q. and A.: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
item.media:description: Muslims praying Sunday in Bali, Indonesia, on the eve of Ramadan.
item.description: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: 5 Catalan Cities Step Away From Spain With New Jewish History Network
item.description: The cities in Catalonia have decided to withdraw from a Spanish network of cities with historic Jewish medieval quarters to create their own network.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Bomb in Istanbul Kills 11 Near Tourist District
item.description: Explosives in a parked car were detonated by remote control as a police shuttle bus passed through the historic Beyazit area during morning rush hour.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Defiant Assad Vows to Retake ‘Every Inch’ of Syria From His Foes
item.description: In a nationally televised speech, President Bashar al-Assad offered no hint of compromise and dimmed any hope for revival of talks to end the war.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Jewish Woman Detained for Taking Torah Scroll to Western Wall in Jerusalem
item.media:description: An Israeli police officer with Lesley Sachs, the executive director of Women of the Wall, who was briefly arrested on Tuesday while carrying a Torah scroll to the Western Wall.
item.description: The woman, Lesley Sachs, the executive director of Women of the Wall, was held for a few hours after she protested restrictions on women at the holy site.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Pall Hangs Over Brazil’s Presidential Palace as Dilma Rousseff Prepares for Trial
item.media:description: Dilma Rouseff, Brazil’s first female president, is allowed to stay at the Palácio da Alvorada, the cavernous residence of the country’s leader, while the fight to oust her once and for all grinds on in the Senate.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Rousseff, Brazil’s first female president, was supposed to be preparing to greet world leaders, not enduring the humiliation of an impeachment battle that has her hanging by a thread.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Political Impasse in Canada Puts Assisted Suicide in Legal Limbo
item.media:description: Health Minister Jane Philpott, right, and Justice Minister Jody Wilson-Raybould at a news conference in April, when the Canadian government introduced a bill on physician-assisted suicide.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Canada’s Supreme Court overturned criminal laws banning assisted suicide last year, and new legislation has not been put into place.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Lieyu Township Journal: Caught Between China and Taiwan, and Leaning Toward China
item.media:description: Cold War-era steel barricades on the shores of Taiwan’s Lieyu Island. The Chinese city of Xiamen is just over three miles away.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: The people of Lieyu Township on Lesser Kinmen Island are linked to Taipei, but have prospered as trade and tourism with the mainland have blossomed.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: U.S. and Beijing Offer Competing Views on South China Sea
item.description: The diverging positions by American and Chinese officials indicated that annual talks had done little to bridge differences.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Kenya’s Collective ‘Uh-Oh’: Another Election Is Coming
item.media:description: A motorcyclist stopped at a burning barricade set up by opposition supporters in the Kibera slum of Nairobi, Kenya, during the weekly protest on what is now known as Tear Gas Monday.
item.description: The contest for president is next year, but protests and violence have already begun. A 5-year-old was shot on Monday, and demonstrations are hurting the economy.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Sinosphere: Michael Puett on the Enduring Lessons of Chinese Philosophy
item.media:description: Tourists and students at the Temple of Confucius in Beijing standing before a statue of the ancient philosopher whose teachings continue to shape Chinese society.
item.description: Rather than embracing ourselves as we are, he says, Chinese tradition challenges us to break out of old patterns and cultivate a different, better self.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Will Abba Take a Chance on a Reunion? Performance in Sweden Fuels Fans Hopes
item.media:description: Abba performed at the United Nations General Assembly in New York in 1979.
item.description: The band members’ appearance together onstage left many followers clinging to what one historian called a .01 percent possibility.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Prosecutors Paint Picture of Murder and Deception at Chinese Coal Mines
item.media:description: A coal mine near Ordos, in Inner Mongolia, China. Prosecutors have indicted 74 people on charges of faking mine accidents, swindling, homicide, fraud and blackmail.
item.description: Dozens have been accused of involvement in the deaths of 17 people whose bodies were used to fabricate mine accidents and extract compensation.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Question of Identity: Why Britain Is Edging Toward ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: A “Vote Leave” rally in Manchester, England. Betting markets still suggest that Britain will remain in the European Union, but recent polls have shown a lead for the “leave” camp.
item.description: Sometimes, one issue can have a big influence on an election. Immigration may turn out to be that issue on June 23.
item.dc:creator: PETER EAVIS

item.title: Sinosphere: China Threatens Jail Time for College Entrance Exam Cheaters
item.media:description: A student emerging from a university entrance exam in Beijing on Tuesday, one of the more than nine million test-takers across China.
item.description: Officials made clear that they planned to enforce a new law making it a crime to cheat, punishable by up to seven years in jail.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Narendra Modi Bolsters India’s Ties With U.S., Thanks to Donald Trump
item.description: Pacts on Tuesday included a crucial step to ratify the Paris climate accord and finishing the purchase of nuclear reactors, with a military deal to come.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Militant Islamists Are Suspected in Slaying of Hindu Priest in Bangladesh
item.media:description: The Hindu priest Anando Gopal Ganguly and his wife, Shefali Ganguly, at their house in Jhenidah, Bangladesh.
item.description: The priest, Anando Gopal Ganguly, was riding a bicycle when three men on a motorcycle attacked him from behind, the police said.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Money, Jobs and Sovereignty: Myth vs. Reality Ahead of ‘Brexit’ Vote
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, the former mayor of London, during the Brexit Battle Bus tour in York, England, in May.
item.description: As Britain prepares to vote on June 23 on European Union membership, both sides of the debate warn of dangerous outcomes. We debunk, or back up, their claims.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Viktor Korchnoi, Chess Giant Who Drew Soviet Ire, Dies at 85
item.media:description: Garry Kasparov, left, took notes as Viktor Korchnoi made a move during the World Chess Championship semifinal in London in 1983.
item.description: Mr. Korchnoi was widely considered one of the best players in history, though he never won a world championship. He defected from the Soviet Union in the 1970s.
item.dc:creator: DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Saudis Pressure U.N. to Remove Them From List of Children’s Rights Violators
item.media:description: Students at the Munadhil school for girls in Saada, Yemen, in April. The city has been bombed extensively.
item.description: A report found a Saudi-led coalition responsible for most of the child deaths and injuries in Yemen last year, but the United Nations removed them from a list of rights violators.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Graft Fighter in Egypt Finds Himself a Defendant in Court
item.media:description: Hisham Geneina, who led Egypt’s anti-corruption agency, on Monday in Cairo.
item.media:credit: David Degner for The New York Times
item.description: Hisham Geneina, who was once the head of Egypt’s Central Auditing Authority, is charged of spreading false news after he said graft had cost Egypt $76 billion.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Confusion in a Romanian Village as 3 Vasile Cepois Run for Mayor
item.description: The citizens of Draguseni, Romania, were presented with a predicament on Sunday when they had to decide who should lead their village.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Kalashnikov, Maker of AK-47, Looks to Rebrand
item.media:description: In Gorky Park in Moscow on the Victory Day holiday, Kalashnikov showed off the company’s weapons and its new logos. This couple was given a souvenir photograph.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: After American sanctions cut off one of its biggest markets, the Russian gun maker embarked on changes that executives say are yielding results.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: European Union Seeks U.N. Approval to Intercept Libya-Bound Arms
item.media:description: Forces loyal to Libya’s United Nations-backed unity government in front of a power plant captured from the Islamic State near Surt last week.
item.description: Europe wants permission to expand an existing naval operation’s mandate from intercepting migrant boats leaving Libya to blocking weapons heading in.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Italy’s Five Star Movement Leads in Rome’s Mayoral Election
item.media:description: Virginia Raggi, the Five Star Movement’s candidate for mayor of Rome, at a fund-raising event in May. She received 35.3 percent of the vote in the first round over the weekend.
item.description: A victory for the movement’s candidate, Virginia Raggi, in a runoff in two weeks would be a blow to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, whose Democratic Party struggled in the first round.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Louvre and Musée d’Orsay Prepare to Reopen as Floodwaters Recede in Paris
item.media:description: Tourists in Paris on Friday walked past empty line markers outside the Louvre Museum, which was closed because of flooding on Seine River.
item.description: The museums closed their doors and moved tens of thousands of artworks to higher floors last week as a precaution against the rain-swollen Seine River.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE

item.title: After Okinawa Car Crash, U.S. Prohibits Its Sailors in Japan From Drinking
item.media:description: A bar frequented by American military personnel on the Japanese island of Okinawa.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The roughly 19,000 Navy personnel in the country were also confined to their bases after a sailor thought to have been inebriated was involved in a car accident.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Joachim Gauck, German President, Won’t Seek Second Term
item.description: Even though the office is largely ceremonial, the announcement could create more problems for Chancellor Angela Merkel.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Bucharest Journal: At Ceausescu’s Villa, Focus Is on Décor, Not Dictatorship
item.media:description: The living room at the Palatul Primaverii, or Spring Palace, where Nicolae Ceausescu lived with his wife, Elena. Visitors are asked to put on plastic shoe coverings before entering the villa.
item.description: The mansion where Nicolae Ceausescu lived with his wife, Elena, during the 24 years he ruled Romania was shrouded in secrecy. It is now a museum.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Ukraine Struggles to Shake Off Legacy of Corruption
item.media:description: Aivaras Abromavicius, the Ukrainian former minister of economy and trade, in Brussels in December 2014.
item.description: The resignation of Aivaras Abromavicius, the economy and trade minister, amid allegations of cronyism was a worrying sign in the fight against graft.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Arrest Made in Killing of Jordanian Intelligence Officers
item.description: Five people were killed in the assault in a Palestinian refugee camp near the capital, Amman. The government called it a terrorist attack.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Sinosphere: Wu Tong on Traversing Musical Boundaries in China
item.media:description: Wu Tong performing on his sheng, a traditional Chinese wind instrument, at the Tianqiao Theater in Beijing on New Year’s Eve.
item.description: Mr. Wu, one of China’s most successful crossover musicians, discusses his new album and what it was like to be a rock musician in China in the ’90s.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Greed, Corruption and Danger: A Tarnished Afghan Gem Trade
item.media:description: An Afghan businessman checked lapis lazuli at his shop in Kabul in March. Afghanistan has long been one of the chief sources of lapis lazuli, a prized gemstone associated with love and purity.
item.description: The government’s muted response to a militia’s takeover of a giant lapis mine suggests an aligning of interests among insurgents and the political elite.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: What in the World: In Croatia, You’ll Finally No Longer Need the Stamp of Approval
item.description: The centuries-old ritual of the rubber stamp and its “clah-thunk” for documents is giving way to digital in a country bogged down by bureaucracy.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH OROVIC

item.title: What in the World: Hong Kong’s Murder Mystery: Who Is Poisoning the Dogs?
item.media:description: An older sign on Bowen Road, a popular dog-walking path, cautioned owners to be vigilant.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Over 200 dogs may have been poisoned since the 1980s, but officials do not know who is responsible or what the motives may be.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals

item.title: What in the World: When West Africans Dress, the Fabric Is the Message
item.media:description: The designs on wax print fabric worn by West African women can be very personal.
item.description: The bold patterns and images on wax print cotton cloth that many women wear may celebrate pop culture, religion, politics or social mores.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Kerrey’s Vietnam Dilemma
item.description: Former Senator Bob Kerrey should not quit his role at the new Fulbright University Vietnam, despite an outcry over his war record.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Aging, but Still Working, in Singapore
item.media:description: Dealing with an aging population is one of the major challenges that Singapore faces as it cements its status as an advanced nation.
item.description: The city-state already has the world’s longest working hours. Soon, it’ll have the longest working lives, too.
item.dc:creator: TASH AW

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Only in Europe Can Britain Be Great
item.description: There’s nothing glorious about isolation. True patriotism shows in voting for a positive role within the European Union.
item.dc:creator: GORDON BROWN

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
